info.game_comments:
2008 College Championship semifinal game 1.
From the Kohl Center at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

(1, 1).clue: (Jimmy and Cheryl of the Clue Crew report from the Babcock Hall Dairy in Wisconsin; Jimmy reads the clue.)  Cows store massive food in the first of four chambers of the stomach as a part of this process that also means "thinking over slowly"

(2, 1).clue: The New York Times wondered if the death of this actor, who plays the Joker, will make "The Dark Knight" darker

(3, 1).clue: Study this language at Bennington & you may take the class on "Svevo & Tozzi"--2 20th century authors

(4, 1).clue: This novel by Pearl S. Buck tells the story of a Chinese farmer & his family

(5, 1).clue: A farmer could tell you that this measurement of land is equal to 43,560 square feet

(6, 1).clue: Pancho Villa State Park is in this state

(1, 2).clue: (Cheryl reads the clue at the Babcock Hall Dairy in Wisconsin.)  To simulate the sucking of a calf & prevent damage to the udder, the milk vacuum uses this type of regular rhythm from the Latin for "beat"

(2, 2).clue: Nytimes.com lauded Hamish Linklater, who plays Julia Louis-Dreyfus' brother Matthew on this sitcom
(2, 2).correct response: The New Adventures of Old Christine

(3, 2).clue: Major in this -ology at Colgate & you'll take "Human Condition" or "Learning and Cognition" before you're a senior

(4, 2).clue: In 2004 Oprah picked "The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter", the first novel by this Southern woman

(5, 2).clue: One quire is 25 sheets of paper, or 1/20th of an ordinary one of these

(6, 2).clue: Before winning an Oscar for "The Color of Money", he placed second in the 24 Hours of Le Mans auto race

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy and Cheryl report from the Babcock Hall Dairy; Cheryl gives the clue.)  DMI, or dry matter intake, correlates with good milk production; cows especially need this component of plant cell walls sometimes called bulk or roughage

(2, 3).clue: In 2008 this Moscow ballet company announced that Yuri Burlakau had been approved its artistic director

(3, 3).clue: For some fun at Willamette University, you can take a course on this; foils, masks & protective jackets are provided

(4, 3).clue: Oprah had an infectious love for Gabriel Garcia Marquez, choosing "One Hundred Years of Solitude" & this 1985 novel
(4, 3).correct response: Love in the Time of Cholera

(5, 3).clue: To correct medieval abuses in trade, this 1215 document standardized measurements for wine & grain

(6, 3).clue: Read all about it:It's the port city at the mouth of the James River in Virginia

(1, 4).clue: (Jimmy reads the clue at the Babcock Hall Dairy.)  For maximum milk yield, you want to keep your cows calm so they don't become excited & release this hormone also called epinephrine

(2, 4).clue: Nytimes.com blogged on the New York Philharmonic's Asian tour, which included a stop in this North Korean capital

(3, 4).clue: It's a synonym for "avarice" & the name of a first-year economics seminar at Swarthmore

(4, 4).clue: This beloved country is the setting of Alan Paton's "Cry, the Beloved Country"

(5, 4).clue: Sizes of these range from 1 to 26 & types include milliners, sharps & tapestry

(6, 4).clue: You might call this amphibian Diemictylus viridescens, but I call it this

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy gives the clue at the Babcock Hall Dairy.)  Centuries ago, a black breed & a white breed mingled to produce this type of cow named for a German region; today, it produces 90% of U.S. milk

(2, 5).clue: "Oil!", a 1927 novel by this muckraker, was on the New York Times Best Seller List in 2008

(3, 5).clue: Now ear this:This famous school at Lincoln Center features courses on "ear training"

(4, 5).clue: James Frey acknowledged "embellishments" in this book after Oprah picked it for her book club

(5, 5).clue: This U.K. measure of 14 U.S. pounds has also been used for 16 pounds of cheese

(1, 1).clue: May 1775: Yay! I'm president of the 2nd Continental Congress! I feel like writing my name in huge letters

(2, 1).clue: Junoesque, meaning having imposing beauty, refers to Juno, the beautiful wife of this Roman God

(3, 1).clue: It's the boiling point of water on the Celsius scale

(4, 1).clue: King's College Chapel & the Fitzwilliam Museum are highlights of this English city

(5, 1).clue: Punish your roommates by rising early each day & learning how to play this instrument

(6, 1).clue: In January of 2007, this company started delivering movies electronically as well as by mail

(1, 2).clue: 1988: Am now a 4-star general! Awesome! 1991: Commencing Operation Desert Storm. Now I'm stormin'!

(2, 2).clue: This constricting snake's name comes from the serpent killed by Apollo

(3, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew squeezes lemon juice into a beaker of tea.)  This type of acid in the lemon acts as a bleaching agent with the dye in the tea, causing the tea's color to fade

(4, 2).clue: Varanasi, home to Baranas Hindu University, is on the left bank of this river

(5, 2).clue: It's the pavement-destroying tool heard here

(6, 2).clue: The life of a teen named Bree, known by this screen name, was an online video phenomenon

(1, 3).clue: 1931: Busted for tax evasion?! I'm going to end up in Alcatraz for that?! That ain't the Chicago way!

(2, 3).clue: This plant named for the goddess of love "eats" insects for the nitrogen that's lacking in the soil where it grows

(3, 3).clue: Rubbing alcohol is listed as 70% alcohol "by" this, meaning each 100 milliliters of the solution has 70 ml of alcohol

(4, 3).clue: Study in this city & you can always knock off for the day & catch some action at the International War Crimes Tribunal

(5, 3).clue: This country's national anthem is heard here

(6, 3).clue: Dylan, Danny & Debra are characters on this web series about young adults navigating a certain crisis

(1, 4).clue: 1897: I'm totally bummed--I've been exiled to Siberia! But diary, I swear that in 1917, I'll lead the October Revolution

(2, 4).clue: This Roman goddess of grain lent her name to the word "cereal"

(3, 4).clue: Ionization energy, what's needed to remove 1 electron from 1 atom, is high for this non-reactive 6-element group

(4, 4).clue: Begun around 1088, the University of this "meaty" northern Italian city is considered the oldest in Europe

(5, 4).clue: The Canada variety of these are heard here

(6, 4).clue: On your cell phone screen, you can shrink down to size artists like Big Pun & this Latino rapper-- they're "Twinz"

(1, 5).clue: April 27, 1945: Ex-world leader now. Bummer! Today, I'll escape Italy & live like it's the 2nd-to-last day of my life

(2, 5).clue: The counselor of Odysseus' son Telemachus, his name is now used to mean an older adviser

(3, 5).clue: The process of coating an object with metal by putting it in, say, a CuSO4 bath through which current is run

(4, 5).clue: The University of Dar es Salaam in this country was once part of the University of East Africa

(5, 5).clue: Year of the inspiring speech heard here:"Ask not what your country can do for you--ask what you can do for your country"

(6, 5).clue: On the CBS.com reality show "InTurn", hot hopefuls vie for a role on this TV soap opera

(0, 0).clue: In 1894, in his West Orange lab, Thomas Edison shot this sport, the first sporting event ever filmed
